<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 330, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/61May/June 20181 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 768, 546]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 758, 586]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 shows the pendulum. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 120, 826, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 342, 333, 360]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 374, 146, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 374, 459, 392]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, measure the distance \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[557, 405, 918, 422]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................ cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 435, 148, 454]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 180, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 467, 895, 485]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 513, 918, 530]]<|/det|>
<form>D = ............................................................ cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 918, 577]]<|/det|>
<pre>The student displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. He measures the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations. The time \(t\) is shown on the stopwatch in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 590, 580, 720]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.3</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[562, 796, 918, 814]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 900, 918, 917]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 420, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 102, 434, 119]]<|/det|>
She uses the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 128, 747, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 335, 532, 352]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 363, 146, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 363, 918, 395]]<|/det|>
She measures the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across the resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{1}\) and the current \(I\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 653, 424]]<|/det|>
Figs. 2.2 and 2.3 show the voltmeter and ammeter readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 180, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 435, 740, 453]]<|/det|>
Write down the readings shown on the meters in Figs. 2.2 and 2.3.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 463, 915, 481]]<|/det|>
\[V_{1} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (2)\]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 534, 484, 700]]<|/det|>

Fig. 2.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 79, 180, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 75, 772, 103]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance of the resistor \(\mathsf{R}_1\) using the equation \(R_1 = \frac{V_1}{I}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 125, 920, 145]]<|/det|>
<form>R_1 = ................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 157, 146, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 157, 918, 206]]<|/det|>
The student measures the potential difference across each resistor in turn. She calculates values for the resistance \(R_{2}\) and \(R_{3}\) of the resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{2}\) and of the resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{3}\). She records her values as:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 215, 917, 268]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}{R_2 = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 4.75\Omega}\\ {}\\ {R_3 = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad 48.1\Omega} \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 280, 917, 313]]<|/det|>
State whether the results suggest that the three resistors have the same value of resistance. Justify your statement by reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 917, 345]]<|/det|>
statement ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 915, 375]]<|/det|>
justification ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 437, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 466, 144, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 466, 918, 515]]<|/det|>
Calculate the combined resistance \(R\) of resistors \(\mathsf{R}_1\) , \(\mathsf{R}_2\) and \(\mathsf{R}_3\) connected in series, using the equation \(R = R_1 + R_2 + R_3\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 542, 920, 561]]<|/det|>
<form>R = ................................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 146, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 575, 918, 624]]<|/det|>
The student checks her result by connecting the voltmeter across all three resistors connected in series. Tick the potential difference reading you would expect to be closest to the reading she obtains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 551, 90]]<|/det|>
Complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 2.4 to show

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 520, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 540, 90]]<|/det|> A student is determining the focal length \(f\) of a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 364, 120]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 140, 202, 155]]<|/det|> 
illuminated

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 152, 892, 240]]<|/det|>

Fig. 3.1 


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 291, 146, 308]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 291, 826, 308]]<|/det|>
The student places the screen a distance \(D = 70.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 322, 918, 354]]<|/det|>
He places the lens close to the screen and moves the lens slowly away from the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 368, 863, 385]]<|/det|>
He measures the distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 774, 416]]<|/det|>
He measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 866, 447]]<|/det|>
He repeats the procedure using values for \(D\) of 75.0 cm, 80.0 cm, 85.0 cm and 90.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 462, 478]]<|/det|>
The readings are shown in Table 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 630, 508]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, \(uv\) for each value of \(D\).

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[305, 551, 692, 734]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 522, 539, 538]]<|/det|>
Table 3.1   


D/cmu/cmv/cmuv/cm²

75.020.754.5
80.020.060.0
85.019.565.8
90.019.071.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the effect of double-walled insulation on the rate of cooling of hot water in a copper container. The student places the copper container inside a larger metal container. He is investigating the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 420, 213]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 229, 314, 244]]<|/det|>
a copper container

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 249, 881, 265]]<|/det|>
a number of metal containers of different diameters (all larger than the copper container)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 270, 281, 284]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 290, 260, 304]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 310, 332, 324]]<|/det|>
a measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 330, 334, 345]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 360, 905, 376]]<|/det|>
<pre>You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 392, 324, 407]]<|/det|>
<pre>In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 422, 616, 438]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 453, 531, 468]]<|/det|>
<pre>• state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 483, 918, 515]]<|/det|>
<pre>• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 530, 683, 545]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 560, 550, 576]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.
